awd_titl_txt: CI-New:  Community Infrastructure Supporting Hardware Acceleration Research and Education
awd_abstract_narration:
Growth in data analytics is driving rapid development in specialized processor technologies, in the form of hardware accelerators. In addition to known accelerators such as the GPUs and FPGAs, exciting new architectures are offering capabilities not previously possible. To support the computer and information science and engineering (CISE) research community in understanding and making the most of these technologies, the University of Virginia (UVA) is developing a CISE Community Research Infrastructure to Support Hardware Acceleration Research and Education (UVA-SHARE).  This cyberinfrastructure gives system researchers access to an environment of diverse accelerators and tools to perform accelerator research, and provides application researchers the necessary resources to develop and test solutions that accelerate research computing applications. 

UVA-SHARE offers researchers a suite of clusters containing a diverse representation of the industry's latest accelerators.  UVA-SHARE users also have access to software tools, libraries, and technical support to make progress with research as soon as possible.  The broader impact of this project will primarily come in the form of the research it enables. Research enabled by UVA-SHARE is expected to make new advances in computer processor technologies, software infrastructure to support diverse accelerators, and enable new applications and new solutions in scientific computing.  The PI team will implement a set of community engagement activities to promote UVA-SHARE. Access and use of this cyberinfrastructure by early-career researchers is especially encouraged. The research will also achieve broader impact by training students in cutting-edge accelerator technologies and fluency across diverse technologies.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

por.por_cntn:
This project acquired a cluster of heterogeneous computing resources to support hardware acceleration research and education, including different models of graphics processing units (GPUs), which are used for high-performance computing and machine learning as well as 3D rendering; and field-programmable gate arrays (FPGAs). which are reconfigurable architectures that allow diverse accelerators to be prototyped. These were made available to researchers throughout the US.

The chief outcomes were threefold. One was development of more efficient hardware to accelerate pattern matching, which is used in a vareity of applications, such as preventing network intrusion and in bioinformatics. Another was development of new techniques to accelerate processing of graphs, which are used to represent a wide variety of datasets involving links among entitiies. A third was development of improved scheduling for heterogeneous compute-cluster resoures, especially in the presence of diverse energy resources, to improve energy efficiency of compute clusters. The outcomes were published in major conferences and journals, as well as PhD dissertations, and much of the software was made publicly available as open-source software so that other researchers and application developers can use the outcomes from this project.

The project also provided many students with research opportunities, including PhD students, masters students, and undergraduate students.


Last Modified: 01/06/2023
Modified by: Kevin Skadron
